page.title: 09BLACK CHERRY FAIR, CHERTSEY
page.content: The right to hold a fair was granted to Chertsey Abbey in l440 by King Henry Vl. It later became known as the Black Cherry Fair and was held for centuries before being discontinued. The fair was revived again in the seventies and is now held every year in July. The procession of floats for the l985 Fair was led by a pipe band. It started from Stepgates School and progressed through the town to Abbey Fields. There was a fun fair for the children and displays by Morris dancers and drum majorettes. A fancy dress competition and Treasure Hunt were organized and the wide variety of stalls included; antiques, tombola and White Elephant. The profits are shared between local charities.
